fields.descriptive_line: Dye-line print of utility furniture made during 1941-1953
fields.physical_description: Dye-line print design for a pedestal dressing table with centre shelf in the utility furniture series.  The design is on a very large sheet of cream-coloured paper which is folded into eight.
fields.title: Board of Trade Utility Furniture; Pedestal dressing table.centre shelf
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C, case 3H, shelf 21
fields.marks:
'<u> 'GENERAL SPECIFICATION</u> /  <u>MATERIALS:</u><u> MATERIALS TO BE ALLOCATED BY THE  BOARD /  OF TRADE TO INDIVIDUAL  MANUFACTURERS. / ALL TIMBER TO BE SEASONED TO A MOISTURE CONTENT OF BETWEEN 12% / AND 14% AND SELECTED, /  SO FAR AS IS POSSIBLE, FREE FROM DEFECTS / ALL TIMBER TO BE FREE FROM SAPWOOD AND  /  INSECT INFESTATION. /  DUE REGARD WILL BE PAID TO THE SELECTION OF /  THE VARIOUS PARTS OF EACH PIECE OF /  FURNITURE SO AS TO ENSURE EVENLY MATCHED / SURFACES. / SOLID TIMBERS AND VENEERS  / WHOLELY OR PARTLY POLISHED WILL  BE OF /  EXTERIOR QUALITY, WHEN PLYWOOD IS VENEERED, BOTH, / SIDES MUST BE VENEERED, THE / VENEERS USED FOR TOPS, DOORS AND / DRAWER FRONTS WILL BE SPECIALLY / SELECTED FOR GOOD FIGURE & / WILL BE WELL MATCHED. THE GRAIN / OF THE VENEERS ON TOPS WILL RUN / FROM END TO END, ON DOORS AND / ENDS THE GRAIN OF VENEERS WIL / RUN VERTICALLY UNLESS OTHERWISE / SHOWN ON DRAWING.  THE GRAIN OF PLYWOOD WHEN VENEERED WILL BE / AT RIGHT ANGLES WITH THE GRAIN / OF THE VENEER.' / </u>
 <u> CONSTRUCTION:</u> /  <u>'ALL EXTERIOR SURFACES TO BE / POLISHED WILL BE SANDPAPERED TO ' SECURE A SMOOTH FINISH. / ON EXTENDING DINING TABLES, UNDER- / NEATH SURFACES OF GUIDES TO BE SAND- / PAPERED SMOOTH AND FELT OR BAIZE  / STRIPS WILL BE FITTED TO THE / UNDERSIDE OF THE CENTRE TOP RAILS / TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE LEAVES. /  ALL PARTS PARTICULARLY JOINTS, TO / BE CAREFULLY AND ACCURATELY / MACHINED, WELL FITTED AND WHRER / JOINTED TO BE WELL GLUED ON ALL / SURFACES AND CRAMPED INTO / POSITION. ALL PANELS WILL BE / PARTICULARLY WELL GLUED (AND  / SCREWED WHRER SHOWN) TO STILES, LINING PIECES AND FRAMES.  INSIDE / DRAWERS, CUPBOARDS AND OUTSIDE / BACKS TO BE SANDPAPERED SMOOTH. / ALL ARRISES TO BE REMOVED. / FURNITURE GLIDES WILL BE FITTED.'</u> /
 <u> 'FINISH:'</u> /  <u>ALL VISIBLE EXTERIOR SURFACES TO BE FINISHED / TO MATCH COLOUR /  BOARDS PROVIDED BY THE  B.O.T. INSIDE / OF ALL DOORS TO BE VENEERED AND  / FINISHED AS EXTERIOR SURFACES. ALL / OTHER EXTERIOR PARTS TO BE STAINED / TO MATCH. DUE REGARD MUST BE PAID TO / THE MATCHING OF ALL VISIBLE / SURFACES BOTH FOR COLOUR AND FINISH. INSIDE OF ALL CARCASES / CUPBOARDS AND DRAWERS TO BE / LEFT CLEAN AND "IN THE WHITE." ' </u>
 <u>'INSPECTION: </u> / <u> THE MANUFACTURER WILL BE /  REQUIRED TO GIVE EVERY FACILITY / TO AUTHORISED BOARD OF TRADE / PRODUCTION OFFICERS FOR THE / EXAMINATION OF MATERIALS, / COMPONENETS AND WORKMANSHIP.'</u> /
 <u> 'STAMPING:</u> / EACH ARTICLE TO BE STAMPED SO AS / TO GIVE A PREMANENT AND EASILY  / LEGIBLE IMPRESSION / OF THE STAMP, INCLUDING THE / DESIGNATION NUMBER, / OF THE SIZE AND IN / THE POSITION SHOWN / ON DRAWING.' </u> / 
<u> CORRECT SIZE OF STAMP / designation no.</u> /

fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.bibliography:
Denney, Matthew. <u>Utility furniture and the myth of Utility 1943-1948. <u>In:</u> Judy Attfield, ed. <u> Utility reassed: the role of ethics in the practice of design.</u> Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1999. pp.110-124. ISBN 0749052777
Leslie, Fiona. <u>Designs for 20th-century Interiors.</u> London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 2000. ISBN 1851773223
fields.history_note:
'With the outbreak of the Second World war in 1939, nearly all design and manufacture in Britain went towards the war effort. After two years, Britain experienced problems with materials supply, particularly wood from the USA.  In 1941 the Government Board of Trade set up the Utility Furniture Scheme as a means of rationing production and consumption of furniture.  The board introduced specifications for controlling the dimensions and materials of pieces of furniture for all over the home: from chairs, kitchen cupboards and wardrobes to babies' play-pens.  The resulting furniture was straight edged, plain and unembellished, in which form very much followed function and construction.  The restrictions went on until 1953, and although Utility furniture furnished many middle-and lower-class homes, it was seen as an austere necessity during the war, and was soon therefore rejected after the restrictions were lifted.'
Fiona Leslie <u>Designs for 20th-century Interiors</u>  London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 2000, p.18.
